org.xlattice.transport

Class IPv4Address

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.xlattice.transport.IPv4Address
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.xlattice.Address

    public final class IPv4Address
extends java.lang.Object
implements org.xlattice.Address
    An IPv4 address + port number combination capable of acting as a Connection endpoint. XXX WHY doesn't this just extend IPAddress? XXX
    Author:
    Jim Dixon

      • IPv4Address

        public IPv4Address(java.lang.String host,
                   int port)
            throws org.xlattice.AddressException
        Create a valid address/port number pair. If the port number passed is zero, an ephemeral port will be bound.
        Parameters:
        host - the host name
        port - the port number, construed as an unsigned short
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if port is out of range
        org.xlattice.AddressException

      • IPv4Address

        public IPv4Address(java.lang.String addr)
            throws org.xlattice.AddressException
        Create an IPv4 address from a formatted string. This must be a dotted quad followed by a colon followed by a port number (A.B.C.D:n). The port number must be present, it has no default.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if port is out of range
        org.xlattice.AddressException

    • Method Detail

      • getInetAddress

        public java.net.InetAddress getInetAddress()
        Returns:
        the IP part of the address as a Java InetAddress

      • getIPAddress

        public byte[] getIPAddress()
        Return a byte array representing the IP address, with the high order part in byte 0. A conventional "dotted quad" IP address maps exactly into this byte array; if the address is A.B.C.D, then byte 0 will be A, byte 1 will be B, and so forth.
        Returns:
        the IP address as a byte array

      • getPort

        public int getPort()

        Returns:

      • isRFC3330notPrivate

        public static boolean isRFC3330notPrivate(byte[] b)
        This method _allows_ blocks which are reserved by IANA but subject to allocation. It does not currently permit use of the loopback interface, 127.0.0.1.
        Returns:
        whether a remote address is routable
